title: Covid Retrospective
content:
These things happened during covid... interesting, no?

BY JANE ROBERTS AND ALEXANDER KENNEDY
03.17.2021

Just over two years since SARS-Cov-2 first emerged in Wuhan, China, the coronavirus has killed more than 6 million and sickened hundreds of millions more around the world. In that time, many governments — from the local to national level — have gone to extraordinary lengths to combat the spread of the deadly pathogen, from closing borders and implementing contact tracing systems to adopting mask mandates and shutting down businesses. Others — including at times the United States — have downplayed the severity of the virus and touted unproven treatments against it.

As health care workers burned out, the development of vaccines brought new hope. But even with billions of shots now in arms, much of the world’s population has yet to receive a single dose. While many people living in low-income countries simply still lack access, pockets of Americans and others have chosen to willfully forgo the vaccine — and push back on efforts to mandate it. Following the rise of Delta, the Omicron variant swept the globe, its sheer numbers inundating hospitals.

While cases declined in many parts of the globe following records in January of this year, a new Omicron subvariant is causing new spikes, including in Hong Kong and the U.K. As the pandemic enters its third year, scientists are scrambling to determine where things are headed next. But what may already be clear, many experts say, is that the coronavirus is likely to become endemic — meaning rather than disappearing, it will become less disruptive as the population builds immunity over time. In the meantime, here’s a look back at how the pandemic has played out in the U.S. so far.

headline: First U.S. Covid Case
content: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention confirm the United States' first case of the novel coronavirus in a man in Washington state. The man reported recently traveling to Wuhan, China, where the virus was first discovered and has been rapidly spreading. He arrived back in the U.S. on January 15, just a couple of days before three major airports began screening passengers for the virus.

headline: Public Health Emergency
content: U.S. Secretary of Health and Human Services Alex Azar declares the coronavirus a public health emergency, just one day after the World Health Organization did the same. President Donald J. Trump issues a proclamation barring foreign nationals — excluding immediate family members of U.S. citizens and permanent residents — from entering the country if they have visited China in the past two weeks.

headline: Whistleblowing Doctor Dies
content: Dr. Li Wenliang, a Chinese ophthalmologist who tried to warn others about the developing outbreak in Wuhan, dies after contracting the virus. In December, Li had sounded an alarm to fellow doctors in a chat room, but was accused of making false statements and quickly silenced by authorities. Mourners across the U.S., and the world, pay their respects.

headline: Cruise Ship Quarantine
content: Following an outbreak on a cruise ship docked at a Japanese port, hundreds of American passengers are evacuated and flown to California and Texas. At least 14 evacuees test positive for the coronavirus — which the World Health Organization has dubbed Covid-19 — and all are subject to a two-week quarantine upon their return to the U.S.

headline: Nursing Home Outbreak
content: Covid-19 spreads among staff and residents at a nursing home in Kirkland, Washington. The facility will go on to be linked to dozens of deaths and face a $611,000 fine for deficiencies that lead to the country’s first major coronavirus outbreak. With many older residents living in close quarters, nursing homes are particularly vulnerable to the virus.

headline: The Pandemic Begins
content: The World Health Organization declares Covid-19 a pandemic, as global cases rise above 118,000 and deaths top 4,000. In a media briefing, WHO director-general Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus advises countries that with measures to “test, treat, isolate, trace, and mobilize their people in the response,” it’s still possible to “change the course of this pandemic.”

headline: Stay at Home
content: California becomes the first state to issue a stay-at-home order for residents, directing them to leave only for exercise and other essential purposes. Many other states will soon follow, with officials banning indoor dining and prohibiting large gatherings, among other measures. Many companies have shut down their offices and asked employees to work from home until further notice.
A highway sign in Los Angeles advises residents to stay home to prevent the spread of Covid-19. Visual: Aydin Palabiyikoglu/Getty

headline: The Rise of Face Masks
content: After weeks of discouraging the use of masks among the general public — in part to ensure supplies remained available to medical professionals — U.S. health officials are now encouraging Americans to wear cloth face coverings to help stop the spread of Covid-19. Instructions for fashioning homemade masks proliferate online, and community members come together to sew masks for those in need.

headline: Mobile Morgues
content: New York City experiences its deadliest day of the Covid-19 pandemic so far, with more than 800 residents passing away from the virus. With morgues and funeral homes overwhelmed, bodies are being stored in refrigerated trucks provided by the Federal Emergency Management Agency or FEMA.

At Icahn Stadium on Randalls Island, members of New York City chapter of the Laborer's Union International, Local 79, build shelving for trailers that will hold the bodies of Covid-19 victims. Visual: Pacific Press/Getty

headline: Beginnings in California
content: Post-mortem testing of two people who died in Santa Clara County in February suggests the coronavirus was circulating in California at least a month earlier than originally thought. According to the county medical examiner, a 57-year-old woman who died on Feb. 6 is now the first known person to die from Covid-19 in the U.S., followed by a 69-year-old man, who died on Feb. 17.

A respiratory specialist peers out through the glass as the BMC medical team performs a tracheostomy on a COVID-19 patient on the ICU floor at Boston Medical Center in Boston. Visual: Erin Clark/The Boston Globe via Getty Images

headline: Spike in Illinois
content: Illinois records its largest single-day Covid-19 spike, with 4,014 new cases recorded. The increase coincides with the state’s increase in testing. “We have not had [a number] in the 4,000 range before,” Ngozi Ezike, head of the Illinois Department of Public Health, tells Block Club Chicago, “but we also have never had tests in the 29,000 range.” As deaths rise and thousands are hospitalized, Gov. J.B. Pritzker asks residents to continue following the state’s stay-at-home order.
People spread out across social-distancing circles at Dolores Park in San Francisco. Jane Tyska/Digital First Media/East Bay Times via Getty Images

headline: U.S. Record
content: The U.S. becomes the first country in the world to surpass 100,000 deaths from Covid-19. Demographic analyses lay bare the racial disparities of that toll. In Alabama, while only 27 percent of residents are Black, they account for 44 percent of Covid-19 deaths. In Michigan, African Americans make up 14 percent of the population but make up 40 percent of deaths in the state.
A couple exchanges vows as part of a virtual wedding ceremony in Morris Plains, New Jersey. Visual: Theo Wargo/Getty Images

headline: Covid Lung Transplant
content: A Chicago woman in her 20s becomes the first known person in the U.S. to receive a double lung transplant for Covid-19. The woman, who was otherwise healthy, developed a severe case of the disease and spent two months in an intensive care unit. Her lungs were so damaged that doctors said a transplant was her only chance at survival.

headline: California Mask Mandate
content: California Gov. Gavin Newsom issues a statewide mask mandate. With coronavirus cases increasing, the Department of Public Health says, the order requires people to wear face coverings in public spaces to “limit the release of infected droplets when talking, coughing, and/or sneezing, as well as reinforce physical distancing."
A young girl walks with her mother on Santee Alley in the Garment District in Downtown L.A., where masks are required for shopping. Visual: Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times via Getty Images

headline: Aerosol Spread
content: The WHO revises its guidance on Covid-19 transmission, acknowledging that it’s possible the virus could be airborne in indoor spaces. The update comes after hundreds of scientists around the world urged the agency to reevaluate its stance. While the WHO maintains that transmission occurs primarily through close contact with infected people, other experts argue that tiny droplets called aerosols might be behind superspreader events.

headline: Florida Takes the Lead
content: Florida now has the worst Covid-19 outbreak in the country, with more than 10,000 new cases announced in a single day. The state reports that out of the 3.2 million tests it has administered so far, 12.1 percent have come back positive — well above the WHO recommendation of 5 percent. Despite the spike, Disney World is open again after being shut down for four months.

Jackson Pijanowski 9, (L) and Bright Owens, (R), who are supporters calling for Hillsborough County schools to reopen protests ahead of a meeting of the school board at the Hillsborough County Public Schools district office on August 6, 2020 in Tampa, Florida. Visual: Octavio Jones/Getty Images

headline: Covid in Kids
content: As Texas parents consider sending their children back to school this fall, Covid-19 testing has slowed and, of the tests that are being administered, around one-fifth are coming back positive. While evidence suggests that children are less likely to experience severe illness than adults, they can and do spread the virus.

headline: College Outbreak
content: More than 1,200 students and 166 employees have tested positive for Covid-19 at the University of Alabama after the school reopened for in-person earlier this month. Other institutions, including the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill and Michigan State have also experienced outbreaks, with both schools shifting to remote learning.

headline: AstraZeneca Concerns
content: AstraZeneca pauses a large study on its Covid-19 vaccine today after a patient in the United Kingdom experienced a suspected serious adverse reaction. A spokesperson told STAT that the company initiated the hold on the Phase 3 trial, which is being conducted at sites across the U.S., “to allow review of safety data.”

headline: School Covid Dashboard
content: Texas launches an online dashboard to track coronavirus cases in public schools. As of today, the dashboard shows 4,519 positive cases, divided fairly equally between students and staff. In addition to reporting cases to the state, schools are still required to notify local health authorities.

headline: Trump Tests Positive
content: President Donald J. Trump and First Lady Melania Trump test positive for Covid-19. Last Saturday, the president held an event at the White House Rose Garden to announce Judge Amy Coney Barrett’s appointment to the Supreme Court. Several attendees have also tested positive, as have many of Trump’s other close contacts.
President Trump exits the White House to head to a rally in Pennsylvania after recovering from Covid-19 earlier this month. Visual: Tasos Katopodis/Getty Images

headline: Voting in a Pandemic
content: As the Nov. 3 presidential election approaches, STAT reports that public health officials are weighing in on how to stay safe while voting in a pandemic. For those who haven’t already submitted their votes by mail or local dropbox, health authorities say common sense precautions like mask wearing, social distancing, and sanitizing pens between voters should help.

headline: California Pauses Reopening
content: California put a hold on its reopening plans today, as the state recorded more than 13,000 new coronavirus cases — its highest single-day total since the pandemic began. Starting tomorrow, 41 of California’s 58 counties will be subject to the highest tier of restrictions, meaning many indoor activities will be closed to the public.

headline: Stay Home for Thanksgiving
content: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is recommending against traveling for next week’s Thanksgiving holiday to prevent the spread of the virus. Celebrations, the agency said, should be limited to people who already live in the same household.
Ignoring CDC guidance not to travel this holiday, travelers wait in line a TSA checkpoint at Orlando International Airport. Visual: Paul Hennessy/NurPhoto via Getty Images

headline: First Vaccine Authorized
content: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration today granted an emergency use authorization for the first vaccine against Covid-19. The shot, developed by Pfizer and BioNTech, will first be made available to nursing home residents and health care workers. Pfizer is set to supply 100 million doses to the U.S. government by March.

headline: Moderna Quickly Follows
content: The FDA issues an emergency use authorization for a second vaccine, approving the federal government’s plan to distribute some 5.9 million doses of Moderna’s vaccine next week. “We likely will see shots in the arm by the very early part of next week, I would hope Monday or Tuesday,” Anthony Fauci, director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, told the Today show this morning.
A health care worker exits the Covid-19 intensive care unit on New Year's Day at the United Memorial Medical Center in Houston, Texas. Visual: Go Nakamura/Getty Images

headline: Texas Hospitalizations Spike
content: Texas reported more than 14,000 Covid-19 hospitalizations today, its highest number since the pandemic began. According to the state’s health department, Thanksgiving and Christmas get togethers helped to drive the rise in cases. Due to the influx of patients, the availability of intensive care unit beds is extremely limited.

headline: New Variants Identified
content: Researchers in Ohio have identified two new variants of the coronavirus in Columbus. Their findings, which have not yet been peer reviewed, suggest that at least one of the variants contains the same mutation found in variants from the U.K. and South Africa. Scientists say the emergence of variants isn’t itself a cause for concern. What’s important is whether they turn out to be more contagious or lead to more severe disease.
People wait outside a Covid-19 vaccine distribution center at the Kedren Community Health Center in L.A. Visual: Mario Tama/Getty Images

headline: U.K. Variant Warning
content: Public health officials are warning Americans that the coronavirus variant first identified in the United Kingdom could become the dominant strain in the U.S. in the coming months — leading to a spike in cases. While it's not yet clear if the variant causes more deaths or severe disease, the CDC is urging people to remain vigilant in their pandemic precautions.

headline: J&J Jab Authorized
content: The FDA greenlights the single dose Johnson & Johnson vaccine under an emergency use authorization. With three options now available, more Americans will be able to get their Covid-19 shots. But because Johnson & Johnson has a lower efficacy than Pfizer and Moderna, public health officials worry that some people may be reluctant to get it.

headline: Spikes Across Country
content: Although millions are now getting vaccinated every day, and caseloads are down across the United States, some pockets of the country are once again rising. According to The Washington Post, Michigan’s daily number of infections has recently increased, as have tallies in Minnesota and Maryland.

headline: One Year In
content: Just over a year into the pandemic, the CDC released data this week showing that Covid-19 was the third-leading cause of death in the U.S. in 2020. Of the approximately 375,000 deaths attributed to the disease caused by the virus, people of color were hit the hardest.

headline: Colleges Split on Vaccines
content: Some U.S. colleges say they will require students to get vaccinated before returning to campus this fall, while others will leave the decision up to individuals. Some schools, including Virginia Tech, don't believe they can legally mandate vaccines that have only received emergency use authorization from the FDA. But legal scholars suggest the larger issue will come from states pushing back on such requirements.

headline: Mask Guidelines Eased
content: The CDC eases mask guidelines for fully vaccinated individuals. Those who have received a two-dose regimen of the Pfizer or Moderna shots, or a single dose of the Johnson & Johnson vaccine, can forgo masks when doing outdoor activities or meeting with friends for outdoor dining. The agency still recommends masking indoors, regardless of vaccination status.

headline: One Step Further
content: The agency relaxed its guidelines further today, giving fully vaccinated individuals the go ahead to ditch their masks and forgo social distancing indoors. While masks will still be required on planes and public transportation, in updating the guidance, the CDC cited three studies supporting the efficacy of the vaccines.

headline: CDC on Breakthrough Cases
content: Following widely publicized reports of Covid-19 infection in fully vaccinated people, a new CDC report suggests that such breakthrough cases are extremely rare. Of the 101 million U.S. adults who had been fully vaccinated by the end of April, the report says, just .01 percent — or about 10,260 — got Covid-19.

People take to the beach in Coney Island to enjoy some fresh air after months of Covid-19 restrictions. Nearly 60 percent of adult New Yorkers have now been fully vaccinated against the virus. Visual: Mathias Wasik/picture alliance via Getty Images

headline: Deaths Top 600,000
content: More than 600,000 people have now died from Covid-19 in the United States, more than any other country so far. Still, public health experts point out, the numbers have ticked up much more slowly since vaccines became available

headline: Crisis of Unvaccinated
content: According to reporting from The Associated Press, most of the people now dying from Covid-19 in the U.S. are unvaccinated. Of the more than 18,000 people who died of the illness last month, only 150, or less than 1 percent, were fully vaccinated. More than a third of those eligible still have yet to receive their first dose of a Covid vaccine.

headline: Missouri Surge
content: Covid-19 cases are rising rapidly in Missouri, increasing 46 percent during the past two weeks. According to ABC News, the CDC has assigned two members of its federal "surge team" to the state — an epidemiologist to work on "genetic sequencing and data analysis, and an adviser who's working with local officials on how to address vaccine hesitancy."

Tens of thousands of fans gather outside Fiserv Forum to celebrate the Milwaukee Bucks 2021 NBA Championship win. With much of Wisconsin's population still unvaccinated, health experts say they expect to see new Covid cases tied to the event. Visual: Jamie Sabau/Getty Images

headline: The Show Goes On
content: An estimated 100,000 people gather at Chicago’s Grant Park today for the kickoff of the city’s Lollapalooza music festival. For some, the event — which requires attendees to show their vaccination card or a recent negative Covid test — signals optimism about the return of live events. But others caution that as the delta variant spreads, many attendees could contract Covid.

headline: Breakthrough Transmission
content: According to CDC director Rochelle Walensky, people who get Covid-19 even after being fully vaccinated can still transmit the virus to others. The revelation prompted the public health agency to revise its guidance once again, recommending last week that fully vaccinated people continue to wear masks indoors. "Our vaccines are working exceptionally well," Walensky told CNN. "They continue to work well for delta, with regard to severe illness and death — they prevent it. But what they can't do anymore is prevent transmission."

headline: Booster Shots Coming Soon
content: As U.S. public health officials warn of potentially waning immunity against the coronavirus in the coming months, booster shots of both the Pfizer and Moderna vaccines are set to become available to American adults in September. While people who received the single dose Johnson & Johnson vaccine will also likely need an additional shot, research is still ongoing.

A boy rides a bicycle past a sign at Pershing School in Orlando advising that face masks are required for students through Oct. 30, 2021. On Aug. 27, a Florida judge threw out Gov. Ron DeSantis' ban on face mask mandates in schools. Visual: Paul Hennessy/SOPA Images/LightRocket via Getty Images

headline: Federal Vaccine Mandates
content: On August 27, 2021, a Florida judge threw out Governor Ron DeSantis' ban on face mask mandates in schools. (Photo by Paul Hennessy/SOPA Images/LightRocket via Getty Images)

headline: Rules Relax in Florida
content: Florida's new surgeon general, Dr. Joseph Ladapo, issued an executive order this week to make quarantine optional for students exposed to Covid-19. While Gov. Ron DeSantis states that the order aims to prevent healthy students from unnecessarily missing school, many public health officials warn that it could fuel asymptomatic transmission.

headline: 700,000 Covid-19 Deaths
content: The U.S. hit a grim pandemic milestone today, as the nation's Covid-19 death toll surpassed 700,000. While vaccines are now available to all Americans 12 and older, tens of millions are holding out and allowing the more contagious delta variant to spread.

headline: Colin Powell Dies From Covid
content: Former U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell has died after a battle with Covid-19. Powell, who held the post under President George W. Bush, was fully vaccinated but had a compromised immune system due to treatment he was receiving for blood cancer.

headline: Pfizer Authorized for Kids
content: The CDC recommended Pfizer's Covid-19 vaccine for children aged 5 to 11 today, expanding eligibility to tens of millions of Americans. While many parents welcomed the news, others — including those who are vaccinated themselves — expressed hesitation about consenting for their kids.
Thousands take to the California State Capitol steps in Sacramento to protest the Covid-19 vaccine mandate for students. Visual: Anibal Martel/Anadolu Agency via Getty Images

headline: Alarm Over Omicron Variant
content: The WHO warned that the omicron variant, which first appeared in South Africa earlier this month, is very likely to spread globally. “Given mutations that may confer immune escape potential and possibly transmissibility advantage, the likelihood of potential further spread of omicron at the global level is high,” the agency said in a technical brief. Though more data is needed, symptoms with the new variant have been reported to be fairly mild.

headline: Covid-19 Holiday Surge
content: With Christmas and New Year's fast approaching, cases of Covid-19 are surging in New York City. In a tweet, Dr. Jay Varma, a health adviser to Mayor Bill de Blasio, wrote that from Dec. 9 to Dec. 12, the city's test positivity rate went from 3.9 percent to 7.8 percent. With a reporting lag of a few days, however, the true rate could actually be higher.

headline: Virus Grounds Flights
content: Covid-19 is upending holiday plans once again, as staffing issues cause hundreds of flight cancellations on Christmas Day. Delta, United, and Alaska, among other airlines, said employees infected with and exposed to the omicron variant left them without the staffing necessary to operate.

headline: Single Day Case Record
content: The U.S. recorded 1.35 million new Covid-19 infections today, the largest single-day total of any country in the world since the start of the pandemic. The record was accompanied by the highest number of patients hospitalized with Covid-19, reaching more than 136,000.

headline: U.S. Drops Vaccine Rule
content: The U.S. Department of Labor is dropping a vaccine mandate for businesses with more than 100 employers, after it was blocked by the Supreme Court. The rule had been aimed at increasing vaccine update, but faced strong pushback from conservative groups.

headline: Vaccine for Kids Delayed
content: The FDA has delayed a decision over whether to authorize the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine for the nation’s youngest children for at least another two months. While the agency had originally planned to make a call by next week, Pfizer and BioNTech recently submitted new data that will require additional review. While parents await the authorization, the agency noted the best way to protect kids is to continue following masking and social distancing guidelines

headline: Masks Come Off
content: Many Americans can once again forgo masks and social distancing, according to new guidelines from the CDC. To assess a community’s risk, the recommendations direct counties to look at a handful of factors, including new Covid-19 cases per 100,000 people and hospital admissions. The agency suggests a tiered approach to masking based on local conditions and individual’s personal health risks.

headline: Living with Covid
content: As the second anniversary of the Covid-19 pandemic approaches this week, public health experts are weighing in on a path to the “next normal.” In a 136-page report released today, the authors — who include Paul Offit, director of the Children’s Hospital of Philadelphia’s Vaccine Education Center, and Jill Jim, executive director of the Navajo Department of Health — suggest the U.S. shift its Covid-19 response to include other respiratory viruses, improve indoor air quality, among other initiatives.

headline: A Fresh Warning
content: Although Covid-19 cases and have declined dramatically since record spikes in January, top White House coronavirus adviser Anthony Fauci is warning Americans to remain vigilant. In the U.K., where restrictions are being lifted and protection from vaccines is waning, cases are rising again due to an Omicron subvariant called BA.2. With the U.S. often following a similar pattern to the U.K., Fauci says new funding for additional vaccine doses and therapeutic treatments is sorely need.
